propertyPractice.q: A Section 25 notice served on 31 August expires on 28 (or 29) February.
propertyPractice.exp: The corresponding date rule applies to shorter months.

propertyPractice.q: Tenants can contract out of compensation rights if occupation is less than 5 years.
propertyPractice.exp: Exclusion of compensation is permitted for short occupation (<5 years).

propertyPractice.q: Security of Tenure allows a tenant to renew their lease automatically.
propertyPractice.exp: It gives a right to *apply* for a new tenancy, not automatic renewal.

propertyPractice.q: LTA 1954 stands for Landlord and Tenant Act 1954.
propertyPractice.exp: The primary legislation governing business tenancies.

propertyPractice.q: Holding Over means remaining in occupation after the contractual term ends.
propertyPractice.exp: Protected tenants have the right to hold over under s.24 LTA 1954.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Friendly' Section 25 notice offers a new lease.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord indicates willingness to grant a new tenancy.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Hostile' Section 25 notice opposes a new lease.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord opposes renewal on statutory grounds.

propertyPractice.q: Section 26 Request is served by the tenant.
propertyPractice.exp: The tenant's formal request for a new tenancy.

propertyPractice.q: Section 27 Notice is used to end a protected tenancy.
propertyPractice.exp: Used by the tenant to terminate the tenancy (usually while holding over).

propertyPractice.q: Rateable Value is used to calculate compensation.
propertyPractice.exp: Compensation is a multiple of the rateable value (s.37 LTA 1954).

propertyPractice.q: Interim Rent is paid while the new lease is negotiated.
propertyPractice.exp: Rent payable during the statutory continuation period (s.24A LTA 1954).

propertyPractice.q: Contracting Out removes security of tenure rights.
propertyPractice.exp: Agreement that the LTA 1954 protections will not apply.

propertyPractice.q: Statutory Declaration is required for short notice contracting out.
propertyPractice.exp: Required if the warning notice is served less than 14 days before completion.

propertyPractice.q: Tenancy at Will provides security of tenure.
propertyPractice.exp: It is a personal arrangement terminable at any time; no security.

propertyPractice.q: A Licence grants exclusive possession.
propertyPractice.exp: A licence is a personal permission; exclusive possession indicates a lease.

propertyPractice.q: Agricultural Tenancies are excluded from the LTA 1954.
propertyPractice.exp: Excluded by s.43; they have their own statutory regime.

propertyPractice.q: Service Tenancies are protected by the LTA 1954.
propertyPractice.exp: Excluded by s.43 as they are granted for employment purposes.

propertyPractice.q: Mandatory Grounds require the court to grant possession.

criminalPractice.exp: Code C 11.18; allowed only if delay risks harm to evidence/persons or serious loss.

criminalPractice.q: Submission of a prepared statement guarantees no adverse inferences will be drawn.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Knight; inferences may still arise if the statement is incomplete or inconsistent.

criminalPractice.q: Police must hold an ID parade if the suspect asks, even if Video ID is available.
criminalPractice.exp: Code D 3.14; Video ID (VIPER) is the primary method unless not practicable.

criminalPractice.q: A 'mixed' interview (answering some questions, refusing others) avoids adverse inferences.
criminalPractice.exp: It risks confusion and the transcript (including 'no comments') is read to the jury.

criminalPractice.q: Criminal damage valued at £4,000 is triable either-way.
criminalPractice.exp: s.22 MCA 1980; Criminal Damage <£5,000 is treated as summary only.

criminalPractice.q: Low value shoplifting (<£200) allows the defendant to elect Crown Court trial.
criminalPractice.exp: s.22A MCA 1980; although treated as summary, the adult defendant retains election rights.

criminalPractice.q: Robbery is an either-way offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.8 Theft Act 1968; Robbery is triable only on indictment.

criminalPractice.q: Burglary under s.9(1)(a) is an indictable-only offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Theft Act 1968; Burglary is triable either-way (unless aggravated s.10).

criminalPractice.q: Common Assault is a summary only offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.39 Criminal Justice Act 1988.

criminalPractice.q: Private prosecutions can be commenced by written charge and requisition.
criminalPractice.exp: s.29 CJA 2003; restricted to public prosecutors. Private prosecutions use 'laying an information'.

criminalPractice.q: There is no time limit for charging an either-way offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Time limits apply to summary offences (6 months); indictable offences have no limit.

criminalPractice.q: Breach of Code D automatically renders identification evidence inadmissible.
criminalPractice.exp: s.78 PACE; the court has discretion to exclude if admission would be unfair.

criminalPractice.q: A solicitor can act as the appropriate adult for their client.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 1.7; a solicitor present in a professional capacity cannot be the AA.

criminalPractice.q: Inferences from silence under s.34 apply if legal advice was refused by police.
criminalPractice.exp: s.34(2A) CJPOA; no inferences if the suspect was denied access to legal advice.

criminalPractice.q: An officer of Inspector rank must supervise a confrontation ID procedure.
criminalPractice.exp: Code D 3.23; Identification Officer must be at least an Inspector.

criminalPractice.q: Theft is a summary only offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.1 Theft Act 1968; Theft is triable either-way.

criminalPractice.q: Assault Occasioning Actual Bodily Harm (ABH) is an indictable-only offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.47 OAPA 1861; ABH is triable either-way.

criminalPractice.q: Summary only offences must be charged within 6 months of the offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.127 Magistrates' Courts Act 1980.

criminalPractice.q: A 'significant statement' must be put to the suspect at the start of the interview.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 11.4A; to allow the suspect to confirm or deny it.

criminalPractice.q: Silence in interview prevents the prosecution from adducing a 'no comment' transcript.
criminalPractice.exp: A 'no comment' interview transcript is generally not read; admissions/mixed interviews are.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Caution' must be given before questioning a suspect about an offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 10.1.

criminalPractice.q: An 'Interview' is questioning regarding involvement in an offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 11.1A definition.

criminalPractice.q: Active defence involves sitting passively and taking notes.
criminalPractice.exp: Active defence involves intervening to protect rights and advance the client's case.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Significant Statement' includes an admission of guilt.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 11.4A.

criminalPractice.q: s.34 CJPOA relates to failure to mention facts relied on at trial.
criminalPractice.exp: Adverse inference provision.

criminalPractice.q: s.36 CJPOA relates to failure to account for objects, substances, or marks.
criminalPractice.exp: Adverse inference provision.

criminalPractice.q: s.37 CJPOA relates to failure to account for presence at the scene.
criminalPractice.exp: Adverse inference provision.

criminalPractice.q: Code D governs Identification Procedures.
criminalPractice.exp: PACE Codes of Practice.

criminalPractice.q: VIPER stands for Video Identification Parade Electronic Recording.
criminalPractice.exp: Standard identification procedure.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Juvenile' is a person under the age of 18.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 1.5.

criminalPractice.q: An Appropriate Adult provides legal advice to the suspect.
criminalPractice.exp: They provide support/communication assistance; legal advice is for the solicitor.

criminalPractice.q: Summary offences are tried in the Magistrates' Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: Indictable-only offences are tried in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: Either-way offences can be tried in Magistrates or Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: Low value shoplifting threshold is £200.
Criminal damage summary threshold is £5,000.
A 'Confrontation' involves a witness seeing the suspect in a line-up.
criminalPractice.exp: Confrontation is 1-on-1; a line-up is an Identification Parade.

criminalPractice.q: Code C governs detention, treatment, and questioning.
criminalPractice.exp: PACE Codes of Practice.

criminalPractice.q: A solicitor must act in the best interests of their client.
criminalPractice.exp: SRA Principle 7.

criminalPractice.q: Laying an information is used to commence a private prosecution.
criminalPractice.exp: Method of commencing proceedings.

criminalPractice.q: Written charge and requisition is available to all prosecutors.
criminalPractice.exp: Restricted to 'relevant prosecutors' (public bodies).

criminalPractice.q: Theft is an indictable-only offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Theft is triable either-way.

criminalPractice.q: An Identification Officer must be involved in the investigation.
criminalPractice.exp: Code D 3.11; must be independent of the investigation.

criminalPractice.q: Group identification involves seeing the suspect in an informal group.
criminalPractice.exp: Code D Annex C.

criminalPractice.q: A suspect has a right to consult the Codes of Practice.
criminalPractice.exp: Code C 3.1.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant on Universal Credit automatically passes the interests of justice test.
criminalPractice.exp: Universal Credit passports the Means Test; the Merits (Interests of Justice) Test must still be passed.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can commit a defendant for sentence if their powers are insufficient.
criminalPractice.exp: s.14 Sentencing Act 2020; allows committal to Crown Court for greater punishment.

criminalPractice.q: An adult charged with criminal damage valued at £4,000 can elect Crown Court trial.
criminalPractice.exp: s.22 MCA 1980; Criminal damage <£5,000 is summary only with no right of election.

criminalPractice.q: An adult charged with low-value shoplifting (<£200) can elect Crown Court trial.
criminalPractice.exp: s.22A MCA 1980; although treated as summary only, the right to elect remains for adults.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can grant bail to a defendant charged with murder.
criminalPractice.exp: s.115 Coroners and Justice Act 2009; only a Crown Court Judge can grant bail for murder.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant refused bail in the Magistrates' Court has a right to appeal to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Requires a 'certificate of full argument' from the magistrates.

criminalPractice.q: The custody time limit for a summary trial in the Magistrates' Court is 70 days.
criminalPractice.exp: The limit is 56 days between first appearance and start of summary trial.

criminalPractice.q: Ideally, a defendant makes their first bail application at the police station.
criminalPractice.exp: Police grant bail (s.37/38 PACE); the first 'application' to a court is at the first hearing.

criminalPractice.q: A plea of 'Guilty, but I didn't mean to do it' is treated as a Guilty plea.
criminalPractice.exp: This is an 'equivocal plea'; the court must treat it as Not Guilty.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can appeal a decision to grant bail for an imprisonable offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Bail (Amendment) Act 1993; must give oral notice at the hearing.

criminalPractice.q: Failure to surrender to bail is a criminal offence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.6 Bail Act 1976; punishable by fine or imprisonment.

criminalPractice.q: A surety must deposit money with the court before the defendant is released.
criminalPractice.exp: A surety promises to pay (recognizance); a 'security' involves depositing money/items.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates must follow the Allocation Guideline when deciding venue.
criminalPractice.exp: s.19 MCA 1980; must consider if sentencing powers are adequate.

criminalPractice.q: If a defendant indicates a Not Guilty plea, the court proceeds immediately to trial.
criminalPractice.exp: The court proceeds to Allocation (Mode of Trial) to decide venue.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant charged with robbery will have a plea before venue hearing.
criminalPractice.exp: Robbery is indictable-only; it is sent forthwith to the Crown Court (s.51 CDA 1998).

criminalPractice.q: The 'No Real Prospect' test prevents custodial remand for minor offences.
criminalPractice.exp: Bail Act 1976 Sch 1 Part 1 Para 9; no remand if no real prospect of custodial sentence.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant can make unlimited repeat bail applications on the same arguments.
criminalPractice.exp: Part 19 CrimPR/Common Law; must show a change in circumstances after the second application.

criminalPractice.q: The Magistrates' Court can sentence an offender for a related summary offence sent to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: If sent under s.51 CDA 1998, the Crown Court deals with the related summary offence.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant can ask for an indication of sentence before electing venue.
criminalPractice.exp: s.17A MCA 1980; the indication is binding if the defendant then pleads guilty.

criminalPractice.q: Breaching a bail condition is a standalone criminal offence.
criminalPractice.exp: It allows arrest and withdrawal of bail, but is not a separate offence (unlike Failure to Surrender).

criminalPractice.q: Initial details of the prosecution case (IDPC) must include a summary of the evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR Part 8; usually a summary and previous convictions.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant detained after charge must appear in court within 48 hours.
criminalPractice.exp: PACE s.46; must be brought before the next available court (usually next morning).

criminalPractice.q: Legal aid for the Crown Court may require an income contribution.
criminalPractice.exp: Income Contribution Orders apply if disposable income exceeds the threshold.

criminalPractice.q: Complex fraud cases can be sent to the Crown Court without allocation.
criminalPractice.exp: s.51B CDA 1998; bypassing the usual mode of trial procedure.

criminalPractice.q: If Magistrates decline jurisdiction, the defendant can still choose summary trial.
criminalPractice.exp: If Magistrates decline, the case MUST go to the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: s.4 Bail Act 1976 creates a general presumption in favour of bail.
criminalPractice.exp: Primary legislation establishing the right to bail.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Representation Order' grants public funding for legal costs.
criminalPractice.exp: Legal Aid funding mechanism.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Interests of Justice' test is the merits test for legal aid.
criminalPractice.exp: Assesses if the case warrants public funding (Widgery Criteria).

criminalPractice.q: 'Surety' is a person who guarantees the defendant's surrender.
criminalPractice.exp: Bail condition requiring a financial recognizance.

criminalPractice.q: 'Security' involves the defendant depositing money/valuables.
criminalPractice.exp: Bail condition; forfeited if they fail to surrender.

criminalPractice.q: 'Summary Only' offences are tried in the Magistrates' Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: 'Indictable Only' offences are tried in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: 'Either-Way' offences can be tried in either court.
criminalPractice.exp: Classification of offences.

criminalPractice.q: 'Plea Before Venue' determines the plea for either-way offences.
criminalPractice.exp: s.17A MCA 1980; procedure before allocation.

criminalPractice.q: 'Allocation' determines the trial venue for either-way offences.
criminalPractice.exp: s.19 MCA 1980; deciding between Mags or Crown.

criminalPractice.q: 'Committal for Sentence' sends a convicted defendant to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.14 Sentencing Act 2020; used when Mags' powers are insufficient.

criminalPractice.q: 'Sending for Trial' transfers indictable cases to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.51 CDA 1998; procedure for moving cases up.

criminalPractice.q: 'IDPC' stands for Initial Details of the Prosecution Case.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR Part 8; evidence served at first hearing.

criminalPractice.q: 'Conditional Bail' imposes restrictions on the defendant's liberty.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., Curfew, Residence, Reporting.

criminalPractice.q: 'Unconditional Bail' requires only surrender to custody.
criminalPractice.exp: Release without restrictions.

criminalPractice.q: 'Remand in Custody' means detaining the defendant in prison.
criminalPractice.exp: Refusal of bail.

criminalPractice.q: 'CTL' stands for Custody Time Limit.
criminalPractice.exp: Maximum time a defendant can be held before trial.

criminalPractice.q: 'Equivocal Plea' is a plea with a defence attached.
criminalPractice.exp: Must be treated as Not Guilty.

criminalPractice.q: 'Passporting' refers to automatic eligibility for legal aid means test.
criminalPractice.exp: Based on age or benefit status.

criminalPractice.q: 'Duty Solicitor' provides free legal advice at court.
criminalPractice.exp: Available for first hearings for imprisonable offences.

criminalPractice.q: Section 51 CDA 1998 governs sending cases to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Statutory authority for transfer.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Merits Test' considers the seriousness of the case.
criminalPractice.exp: Widgery Criteria; distinct from the Means Test.

criminalPractice.q: Failure to Surrender is punishable by imprisonment.
criminalPractice.exp: Bail Act 1976 s.6; creates a distinct offence.

criminalPractice.q: s.4 Bail Act exceptions are listed in Schedule 1.
criminalPractice.exp: Exceptions to the right to bail.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Certificate of Full Argument' is needed to appeal bail.
criminalPractice.exp: Procedural requirement for Crown Court bail application.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant found unfit to plead can be given a custodial sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: The only options are a hospital order, supervision order, or absolute discharge.

criminalPractice.q: If a defendant is unfit to plead, the jury determines if they had the mens rea.
criminalPractice.exp: The jury determines if they committed the act (actus reus), not the mens rea.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution must disclose material that is neutral to the case.
criminalPractice.exp: Disclosure is required only if it undermines the prosecution or assists the defence.

criminalPractice.q: A defence statement is mandatory in the Magistrates' Court.
criminalPractice.exp: It is voluntary in the Magistrates' Court but mandatory in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: Failure to serve a defence statement prevents the accused from calling alibi witnesses.
criminalPractice.exp: The court cannot prevent the witness being called; the sanction is adverse inferences.

criminalPractice.q: The defence statement must be served within 28 days of prosecution initial disclosure.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR 15.4; strict time limit for Crown Court defence statements.

criminalPractice.q: A s.8 application for specific disclosure can be made without serving a defence statement.
criminalPractice.exp: Service of a defence statement is a prerequisite for a s.8 application.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution's duty of disclosure ends once the trial begins.
criminalPractice.exp: It is a continuing duty until conviction, acquittal, or discontinuation.

criminalPractice.q: A s.9 statement is admissible as evidence if the other party does not object.
criminalPractice.exp: s.9 CJA 1967 allows statements to be read if agreed/uncontested.

criminalPractice.q: Judicial notice 'on enquiry' allows a judge to research indisputable facts.
criminalPractice.exp: Judges can look up generally known facts; jurors cannot research.

criminalPractice.q: An application to dismiss a charge must be made after arraignment.
criminalPractice.exp: It must be made *before* the defendant is arraigned.

criminalPractice.q: Under Galbraith, a judge must stop the case if the evidence is weak or vague.
criminalPractice.exp: Only if a properly directed jury *could not* properly convict on it.

criminalPractice.q: Section 78 PACE can be used to exclude defence evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.78 applies only to evidence on which the *prosecution* proposes to rely.

criminalPractice.q: Abuse of process can be argued if the police destroy evidence assisting the defence.
criminalPractice.exp: This can undermine the integrity of the justice system.

criminalPractice.q: A confession obtained by oppression must be excluded even if it is true.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(2)(a) PACE; the court 'shall not allow' it, regardless of truth.

criminalPractice.q: Facts discovered as a result of an excluded confession are inadmissible.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(4) PACE allows facts discovered to be admitted (no 'fruit of poisoned tree').

criminalPractice.q: Denying a solicitor to a vulnerable suspect renders a confession unreliable under s.76(2)(b).
criminalPractice.exp: R v McGovern; breach of Code C likely renders confession unreliable.

criminalPractice.q: A nod or gesture can constitute a 'confession' under PACE.
criminalPractice.exp: s.82(1) PACE defines confession as words 'or otherwise'.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that a confession was not obtained by oppression.
criminalPractice.exp: Once raised, the burden is on the prosecution to disprove oppression.

criminalPractice.q: The court can raise s.76 confession issues of its own motion.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(3) PACE allows the court to require proof of admissibility.

criminalPractice.q: A 'mixed' statement (part admission, part exculpatory) is a confession.
criminalPractice.exp: s.82(1) PACE; 'wholly or partly adverse'.

criminalPractice.q: Breach of Code C automatically renders a confession inadmissible.
criminalPractice.exp: Breaches must be significant/substantial to trigger exclusion under s.76 or s.78.

criminalPractice.q: A voir dire is held in the presence of the jury.
criminalPractice.exp: It is a 'trial within a trial' held in the absence of the jury.

criminalPractice.q: The defence can apply to exclude a confession under both s.76 and s.78.
criminalPractice.exp: They are often argued in the alternative.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can tell the jury that a body was found because the defendant confessed.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(5) PACE prohibits linking the discovery to the excluded statement.

criminalPractice.q: PTPH stands for Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing.
criminalPractice.exp: The main pre-trial hearing in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: 'Arraignment' is the process of putting the indictment to the defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: Occurs at the plea stage of the PTPH.

criminalPractice.q: 'Used material' is material the prosecution relies on at trial.
criminalPractice.exp: Evidence served on the defence.

criminalPractice.q: 'Unused material' must be recorded on a schedule.
criminalPractice.exp: Usually the MG6C schedule.

criminalPractice.q: CPIA stands for Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996.
criminalPractice.exp: Primary legislation governing disclosure.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Defence Statement' sets out the nature of the accused's defence.
criminalPractice.exp: Defined in s.6A CPIA 1996.

criminalPractice.q: s.11 CPIA allows adverse inferences from disclosure failures.
criminalPractice.exp: Sanction for failing to serve/inadequate defence statement.

criminalPractice.q: PII stands for Public Interest Immunity.
criminalPractice.exp: Application to withhold sensitive material.

criminalPractice.q: 'Facts in issue' are facts a party must prove to succeed.
criminalPractice.exp: Elements of the offence or defence.

criminalPractice.q: s.10 CJA 1967 deals with Formal Admissions.
criminalPractice.exp: Agreeing facts in writing.

criminalPractice.q: 'Real evidence' refers to material objects produced for inspection.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., the knife used in an attack.

criminalPractice.q: The jury is the 'Tribunal of Fact' in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: They determine the facts; the judge determines the law.

criminalPractice.q: 'Admissibility' is a question of law for the judge.
criminalPractice.exp: Determined by the Tribunal of Law.

criminalPractice.q: Galbraith provides the test for 'No Case to Answer'.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Galbraith [1981].

criminalPractice.q: s.78 PACE relates to the exclusion of unfair evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Discretionary exclusion power.

criminalPractice.q: s.82(1) PACE defines a 'confession'.
criminalPractice.exp: Includes statements wholly or partly adverse.

criminalPractice.q: A purely exculpatory statement is a confession.
criminalPractice.exp: Must be wholly or partly adverse to the maker.

criminalPractice.q: s.76(2)(a) PACE deals with exclusion for oppression.
criminalPractice.exp: Mandatory exclusion if oppression proved.

criminalPractice.q: s.76(2)(b) PACE deals with exclusion for unreliability.
criminalPractice.exp: Mandatory exclusion if unreliability proved.

criminalPractice.q: 'Oppression' includes torture or inhuman treatment.
criminalPractice.exp: Defined in s.76(8) PACE.

criminalPractice.q: A judge must withdraw a case if identification evidence is poor and unsupported.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Turnbull; if ID is poor and unsupported, the judge should direct an acquittal.

criminalPractice.q: A Turnbull warning is required even if the witness recognizes the defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Turnbull; mistakes can be made even in recognition cases.

criminalPractice.q: Breach of Code D automatically renders identification evidence inadmissible under s.78.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Ryan; breaches do not automatically lead to exclusion unless they cause unfairness.

criminalPractice.q: A 'dock identification' is the standard method for identifying a defendant at trial.
criminalPractice.exp: It is exceptional and undesirable due to prejudice; formal ID procedures are preferred.

criminalPractice.q: The defence bears the legal burden of proving self-defence.
criminalPractice.exp: The defence bears only the evidential burden; the prosecution must disprove it beyond reasonable doubt.

criminalPractice.q: Under Galbraith, a judge should stop a case if the evidence is merely inconsistent.
criminalPractice.exp: Inconsistency/reliability is for the jury; the judge stops it only if no jury *could* properly convict.

criminalPractice.q: A confession obtained by oppression must be excluded, even if true.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(2)(a) PACE; the court 'shall not allow' it, protecting the integrity of the system.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that a confession was not obtained by oppression.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(2) PACE; the burden of proof is on the prosecution once the issue is raised.

criminalPractice.q: Facts discovered as a result of an inadmissible confession are also inadmissible.
criminalPractice.exp: s.76(4) PACE; facts discovered (e.g., location of a weapon) remain admissible.

criminalPractice.q: A 'voir dire' is required if the defence challenges the truth of a confession.
criminalPractice.exp: A voir dire determines *admissibility* (voluntariness), not truth (which is for the jury).

criminalPractice.q: In the Magistrates' Court, s.76 applications must be heard as a preliminary issue.
criminalPractice.exp: Magistrates must decide admissibility before continuing (or retrying if excluded).

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution must disclose material that undermines their case or assists the defence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.3 CPIA 1996; the statutory test for initial and continuing disclosure.

criminalPractice.q: A Defence Statement is mandatory in the Magistrates' Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.5 CPIA 1996; it is mandatory in the Crown Court, voluntary in the Magistrates' Court.

criminalPractice.q: The time limit for serving a Defence Statement in the Crown Court is 14 days.
criminalPractice.exp: It is 28 days from compliance with initial prosecution disclosure (s.5 CPIA/CrimPR).

criminalPractice.q: Failure to serve a Defence Statement can lead to adverse inferences at trial.
criminalPractice.exp: s.11 CPIA 1996; inferences can be drawn for failure to serve or late service.

criminalPractice.q: A s.8 application for specific disclosure requires a Defence Statement to be served first.
criminalPractice.exp: s.8 CPIA 1996; the defence must set out their case to justify the request.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can make a closing speech if the defendant is unrepresented and gives no evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Prosecution cannot make a closing speech if an unrepresented D calls no witnesses.

criminalPractice.q: A judge can exclude prosecution evidence under s.78 if it would have an adverse effect on fairness.
criminalPractice.exp: s.78 PACE; the discretionary power to exclude unfair evidence.

criminalPractice.q: s.78 PACE can be used to exclude evidence adduced by a co-defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: s.78 applies only to evidence on which the *prosecution* proposes to rely.

criminalPractice.q: If a submission of no case to answer succeeds, the judge directs a verdict of not guilty.
criminalPractice.exp: The case stops, and the defendant is acquitted.

criminalPractice.q: A Turnbull warning must instruct the jury that a mistaken witness cannot be convincing.
criminalPractice.exp: It must warn that a mistaken witness *can* be convincing.

criminalPractice.q: The defence opening speech occurs before the prosecution evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: It occurs after the prosecution case closes and before defence evidence (if calling witnesses).

criminalPractice.q: Supporting evidence in a Turnbull case must be independent of the identification.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Turnbull; e.g., forensics, admissions, or silence (if adverse inference applies).

criminalPractice.q: An alibi witness must be notified to the prosecution in the Defence Statement.
criminalPractice.exp: s.6A CPIA 1996; details of alibi witnesses must be provided.

criminalPractice.q: The judge determines the facts in a Newton Hearing.
criminalPractice.exp: A Newton hearing (trial of issue) is decided by the judge alone, even in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: R v Turnbull establishes guidelines for identification evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Key case for disputed visual identification.

criminalPractice.q: ADVOKATE is a mnemonic for identification factors.
criminalPractice.exp: Amount of time, Distance, Visibility, Obstruction, Known, Any reason to remember, Time lapse, Errors.

criminalPractice.q: s.76 PACE relates to the exclusion of confessions.
criminalPractice.exp: Mandatory exclusion for oppression or unreliability.

criminalPractice.q: s.78 PACE provides discretion to exclude unfair evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Discretionary exclusion ('shall not allow' is s.76).

criminalPractice.q: 'Oppression' includes torture or inhuman treatment.
criminalPractice.exp: Defined in s.76(8) PACE.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Legal Burden' is the obligation to prove a fact.
criminalPractice.exp: Usually rests on the prosecution (Woolmington).

criminalPractice.q: The 'Standard of Proof' for the prosecution is beyond reasonable doubt.
criminalPractice.exp: Woolmington v DPP; 'so that you are sure'.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Standard of Proof' for the defence is the balance of probabilities.
criminalPractice.exp: Applies when the defence bears a legal burden (e.g., insanity).

criminalPractice.q: An 'Evidential Burden' is the burden to raise an issue.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., raising 'some evidence' of self-defence.

criminalPractice.q: Galbraith provides the test for 'No Case to Answer'.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Galbraith [1981].

criminalPractice.q: CPIA stands for Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996.
criminalPractice.exp: Primary legislation governing disclosure.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Voir Dire' is a trial within a trial.
criminalPractice.exp: Procedure to determine admissibility in the absence of the jury.

criminalPractice.q: s.82(1) PACE defines a 'Confession'.
criminalPractice.exp: Includes statements wholly or partly adverse.

criminalPractice.q: 'Unused Material' is material not relied upon by the prosecution.
criminalPractice.exp: Must be disclosed if it meets the s.3 test.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Golden Rule' of disclosure requires full disclosure of undermining material.
criminalPractice.exp: R v H and C [2004].

criminalPractice.q: A 'Submission of No Case to Answer' is made after the prosecution case.
criminalPractice.exp: Half-time submission.

criminalPractice.q: 'PII' stands for Public Interest Immunity.
criminalPractice.exp: Application to withhold sensitive material.

criminalPractice.q: The jury is the 'Tribunal of Fact' in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: They determine the facts; the judge determines the law.

criminalPractice.q: s.9 CJA 1967 allows witness statements to be read.
criminalPractice.exp: If agreed by parties.

criminalPractice.q: s.10 CJA 1967 allows formal admissions of fact.
criminalPractice.exp: Agreed facts presented in writing.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Review Officer' is responsible for disclosure in the police station.
criminalPractice.exp: The 'Disclosure Officer' is responsible; Review Officer reviews detention.

criminalPractice.q: 'ADVOKATE' 'T' stands for Time lapse.
criminalPractice.exp: Time between observation and identification.

criminalPractice.q: 'ADVOKATE' 'V' stands for Visibility.
criminalPractice.exp: Lighting conditions etc.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Turnbull Warning' urges caution in relying on identification.
criminalPractice.exp: Mandatory direction in disputed ID cases.

criminalPractice.q: s.3 CPIA 1996 sets the test for initial prosecution disclosure.
criminalPractice.exp: Undermine prosecution / assist defence.

criminalPractice.q: The court must exclude defendant bad character evidence under s.101(3) if it is unfair.
criminalPractice.exp: s.101(3) CJA 2003; 'must' exclude if admission has adverse effect on fairness (Gateways D & G only).

criminalPractice.q: A defendant can use s.78 PACE to exclude bad character evidence adduced by a co-defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: s.78 PACE applies only to evidence on which the *prosecution* proposes to rely.

criminalPractice.q: A previous conviction for burglary automatically establishes a propensity to be untruthful.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Hanson; dishonesty offences do not automatically show a propensity to be untruthful.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can adduce evidence of a previous acquittal to show propensity.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Z; double jeopardy does not prevent using acquittals as evidence of propensity.

criminalPractice.q: Evidence of a defendant's motive to commit the offence falls within s.98 bad character.
criminalPractice.exp: s.98(a) CJA 2003; motive has 'to do with the alleged facts' so it is NOT bad character.

criminalPractice.q: A Defence Statement must be served within 14 days of initial disclosure in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR 15.4; the time limit is 28 days in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: Failure to serve a Defence Statement in the Crown Court can lead to adverse inferences.
criminalPractice.exp: s.11 CPIA 1996; inferences can be drawn for failure to serve or late service.

criminalPractice.q: A s.8 application for specific disclosure can be made before a Defence Statement is served.
criminalPractice.exp: s.8 CPIA 1996; the defendant must have served a defence statement first.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution has a continuing duty to review disclosure until the defendant is acquitted or convicted.
criminalPractice.exp: s.7A CPIA 1996; the duty continues throughout the proceedings.

criminalPractice.q: Third parties (e.g., banks) have a statutory duty of disclosure under the CPIA.
criminalPractice.exp: There is no statutory duty; the prosecution must issue a witness summons to obtain third-party material.

criminalPractice.q: A Public Interest Immunity (PII) application is made in the presence of the defence.
criminalPractice.exp: PII applications are usually ex parte (without the defence present) to protect the sensitive material.

criminalPractice.q: A youth jointly charged with an adult will have their first hearing in the Youth Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.46 CYPA 1933; they appear in the Adult Magistrates' Court for the first hearing.

criminalPractice.q: A youth can be remitted to the Youth Court for trial after being sent to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: R v W; once lawfully before the Crown Court, there is no power to remit for trial.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant has an absolute right to change their plea from Guilty to Not Guilty.
criminalPractice.exp: It is at the discretion of the court, exercised sparingly (e.g., for improper pressure/mistake).

criminalPractice.q: Notice to adduce prosecution bad character evidence in the Crown Court is 10 business days.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR 21.4; 10 business days after a not guilty plea.

criminalPractice.q: Evidence attacking a deceased person's character triggers gateway (g).
criminalPractice.exp: s.106 CJA 2003; attack on 'another person' includes those who are dead.

criminalPractice.q: Leave of the court is required for a defendant to adduce their own bad character (Gateway b).
criminalPractice.exp: s.101(1)(b) CJA 2003; no leave is required for the defendant to adduce their own record.

criminalPractice.q: Gateway (e) 'Co-defendant' applies only if the defence undermines the co-defendant's defence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.104 CJA 2003; specifically regarding propensity to be untruthful.

criminalPractice.q: Only the prosecution can adduce evidence to correct a false impression (Gateway f).
criminalPractice.exp: s.105(7) CJA 2003; restricted to prosecution evidence.

criminalPractice.q: Propensity to commit offences can be shown by a single previous conviction.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Hanson; possible if the conviction shows a tendency towards unusual behaviour.

criminalPractice.q: Non-defendant bad character can be admitted if all parties agree.
criminalPractice.exp: s.100(1)(c) CJA 2003; agreement bypasses the 'substantial probative value' test.

criminalPractice.q: A defence statement in the Magistrates' Court is mandatory.
criminalPractice.exp: s.5 CPIA 1996; it is voluntary in the Magistrates' Court.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution must disclose evidence that strengthens the defence case.
criminalPractice.exp: s.3 CPIA 1996; the core test for initial disclosure.

criminalPractice.q: Post-offence conduct can be evidence of propensity.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Hanson; if it shows the propensity is ongoing.

criminalPractice.q: Special measures for witnesses in fear include the use of an intermediary.
criminalPractice.exp: YJCEA 1999; intermediaries are for vulnerable witnesses, not merely those in fear.

criminalPractice.q: s.98 CJA 2003 defines 'Bad Character'.
criminalPractice.exp: Evidence of/disposition towards misconduct.

criminalPractice.q: s.112 CJA 2003 defines 'Misconduct'.
criminalPractice.exp: Commission of an offence or reprehensible behaviour.

criminalPractice.q: Gateway (a) is 'Agreement of the parties'.
Gateway (c) is 'Important Explanatory Evidence'.
Gateway (d) relates to 'Propensity'.
criminalPractice.exp: s.101(1)(d) Relevant to an important matter in issue.

criminalPractice.q: Gateway (e) relates to 'Co-Defendants'.
criminalPractice.exp: s.101(1)(e) Substantial probative value between D and Co-D.

criminalPractice.q: Gateway (f) relates to 'False Impressions'.
criminalPractice.exp: s.101(1)(f) Evidence to correct a false impression.

criminalPractice.q: Gateway (g) relates to 'Attack on another's character'.
s.100 CJA 2003 governs Non-Defendant Bad Character.
criminalPractice.exp: Rules for witnesses or non-parties.

criminalPractice.q: CPIA 1996 governs Disclosure.
criminalPractice.exp: Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996.

criminalPractice.q: s.6A CPIA sets out the contents of a Defence Statement.
criminalPractice.exp: Requires nature of defence, facts disputed, and points of law.

criminalPractice.q: MG6C is the schedule of unused material.
criminalPractice.exp: Standard police form for disclosure schedules.

criminalPractice.q: PTPH stands for Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing.
criminalPractice.exp: Main case management hearing in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: CrimPR Part 21 governs Bad Character procedure.
criminalPractice.exp: Rules for notices and applications.

criminalPractice.q: CrimPR Part 15 governs Disclosure procedure.
criminalPractice.exp: Rules for initial and defence disclosure.

criminalPractice.q: s.103 CJA 2003 defines 'Matter in Issue'.
criminalPractice.exp: Includes propensity to commit offences or be untruthful.

criminalPractice.q: 'Reprehensible behaviour' implies moral blameworthiness.
criminalPractice.exp: Case law definition for misconduct.

criminalPractice.q: s.101(3) provides the court's discretion to exclude.
criminalPractice.exp: Must exclude if it has an adverse effect on fairness (Gateways d/g).

criminalPractice.q: The 'Disclosure Officer' examines retained material.
criminalPractice.exp: Disclosure Code of Practice role.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Special Measure' assists vulnerable witnesses.
criminalPractice.exp: YJCEA 1999; e.g., screens or live link.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Interests of Justice' test applies to joint trials.
criminalPractice.exp: Sentencing Council Guideline; youth charged with adult.

criminalPractice.q: s.51 CDA 1998 governs sending youths to Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Crime and Disorder Act 1998.

criminalPractice.q: Arraignment is the taking of the plea.
criminalPractice.exp: Occurs at the PTPH.

criminalPractice.q: 'Theft' is a category of offence for propensity (s.103).
criminalPractice.exp: Categories of Offences Order 2004.

criminalPractice.q: s.107 CJA 2003 allows stopping the case for contamination.
criminalPractice.exp: If bad character evidence is contaminated and conviction unsafe.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can compel a spouse to testify in a theft trial.
criminalPractice.exp: s.80 PACE; spouses are generally not compellable for the prosecution unless specific exceptions (e.g. assault) apply.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant is competent to give evidence for the prosecution against a co-defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: A defendant is not competent as a prosecution witness in their own trial.

criminalPractice.q: The jury must accept expert evidence if it is uncontradicted.
criminalPractice.exp: The jury is not obliged to accept expert evidence unless it leads inevitably to one conclusion.

criminalPractice.q: Under s.116 CJA 2003, anonymous hearsay statements are admissible.
criminalPractice.exp: s.116(1)(b) requires the maker of the statement to be identified.

criminalPractice.q: A previous inconsistent statement admitted under s.119 is evidence of the truth of its contents.
criminalPractice.exp: s.119 CJA 2003; changes the common law where it only went to credibility.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can make a closing speech if an unrepresented defendant gives evidence alone.
criminalPractice.exp: Prosecution can only close if D is represented or calls at least one other factual witness.

criminalPractice.q: A judge can direct a jury to return a verdict of guilty.
criminalPractice.exp: A judge can direct a 'not guilty' verdict (Galbraith) but never a 'guilty' verdict.

criminalPractice.q: Multiple hearsay is generally admissible under s.117 business documents.
criminalPractice.exp: s.121 CJA 2003 allows multiple hearsay if the document fits s.117 requirements.

criminalPractice.q: The defence has an absolute right to make an opening speech.
criminalPractice.exp: Only if calling at least one witness to fact other than the defendant.

criminalPractice.q: A request for drugs via text message is hearsay evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Twist; a request/question is not a 'statement of a matter', so not hearsay.

criminalPractice.q: The court must accept a majority verdict after 2 hours of deliberation.
criminalPractice.exp: The court *may* accept one, but only if reasonable time has elapsed (min 2 hours 10 mins).

criminalPractice.q: A witness statement read under s.9 CJA 1967 is hearsay.
criminalPractice.exp: It is an out-of-court statement admitted for its truth, but admissible by agreement.

criminalPractice.q: A judge can exclude a business document under s.117 if its reliability is doubtful.
criminalPractice.exp: s.117(7) CJA 2003; specific discretion to exclude business documents.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Interests of Justice' gateway (s.114(1)(d)) is a routine way to admit hearsay.
criminalPractice.exp: It is a residual discretion ('safety valve') not to be used to circumvent other sections.

criminalPractice.q: A spouse can be compelled to give evidence for the defence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.80 PACE; a spouse is compellable for the defendant (their partner).

criminalPractice.q: Hearsay notice must be served by the prosecution within 10 business days of a not guilty plea.
criminalPractice.exp: In the Crown Court it is 10 days; in Magistrates' Court it is 20 business days.

criminalPractice.q: A confession is admissible under the Res Gestae exception.
criminalPractice.exp: s.118 CJA 2003 preserves the common law rules including Res Gestae and Confessions.

criminalPractice.q: The Galbraith test asks if the prosecution case is 'weak or vague'.
criminalPractice.exp: Weak/vague evidence goes to the jury; the test is if a jury *could* properly convict.

criminalPractice.q: Legal professional privilege can be waived by the lawyer.
criminalPractice.exp: Privilege belongs to the client and can only be waived by them.

criminalPractice.q: A view of a crime scene is not considered evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Observations made during a 'view' become evidence in the case.

criminalPractice.q: The defence must serve hearsay notice as soon as reasonably practicable.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR Part 20; no fixed day limit for defence, unlike prosecution.

criminalPractice.q: A witness in fear can automatically have their statement read under s.116.
criminalPractice.exp: s.116(2)(e) requires leave of the court; it is not automatic.

criminalPractice.q: If a defendant refuses to testify, the jury can draw an adverse inference.
criminalPractice.exp: s.35 CJPOA 1994; provided the appropriate warning is given.

criminalPractice.q: The judge sums up the facts before the law.
criminalPractice.exp: The judge deals with legal directions first, then sums up the evidence.

criminalPractice.q: A solicitor can invoke privilege to protect a spouse from incrimination.
criminalPractice.exp: Privilege against self-incrimination applies only to the witness themselves.

criminalPractice.q: Hearsay is defined in s.114 CJA 2003.
criminalPractice.exp: Statement not made in oral evidence adduced as evidence of matter stated.

criminalPractice.q: Original evidence is admissible if relevant.
criminalPractice.exp: Evidence adduced to prove a statement was made, not its truth.

criminalPractice.q: R v Twist provides the test for identifying hearsay.
criminalPractice.exp: Three-stage test: Matter to prove -> Statement? -> Purpose?

criminalPractice.q: s.116 CJA 2003 covers unavailable witnesses.
criminalPractice.exp: Dead, unfit, outside UK, cannot be found, fear.

criminalPractice.q: s.117 CJA 2003 covers business documents.
criminalPractice.exp: Created in course of trade/business etc.

criminalPractice.q: Res Gestae is a statutory hearsay exception.
criminalPractice.exp: It is a common law exception preserved by s.118.

criminalPractice.q: Multiple hearsay is generally inadmissible.
criminalPractice.exp: s.121 CJA 2003 restricts hearsay upon hearsay.

criminalPractice.q: Competence refers to whether a witness may lawfully testify.
criminalPractice.exp: General rule: everyone is competent.

criminalPractice.q: Compellability refers to forcing a witness to testify.
criminalPractice.exp: Most competent witnesses are compellable.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Hostile Witness' gives evidence adverse to the calling party.
criminalPractice.exp: Can be cross-examined by own side with leave.

criminalPractice.q: Leading questions are permitted in cross-examination.
criminalPractice.exp: Standard advocacy practice to control the witness.

criminalPractice.q: Leading questions are generally banned in examination-in-chief.
criminalPractice.exp: Witness must give their own account.

criminalPractice.q: Legal Professional Privilege protects lawyer-client comms.
criminalPractice.exp: Confidentiality protection.

criminalPractice.q: Litigation Privilege requires litigation to be in contemplation.
criminalPractice.exp: Dominant purpose test.

criminalPractice.q: The 'burden of proof' usually lies with the prosecution.
criminalPractice.exp: Woolmington v DPP.

criminalPractice.q: The standard of proof is 'beyond reasonable doubt'.
criminalPractice.exp: Often described as 'so that you are sure'.

criminalPractice.q: Submission of no case to answer happens after defence evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: It happens at the close of the prosecution case ('half-time').

criminalPractice.q: Closing speeches occur before the summing up.
criminalPractice.exp: Pros closing -> Defence closing -> Summing up.

criminalPractice.q: The jury is the 'Tribunal of Fact'.
criminalPractice.exp: They decide the facts; judge decides the law.

criminalPractice.q: The judge is the 'Tribunal of Law'.
criminalPractice.exp: Decides admissibility and directs jury on law.

criminalPractice.q: s.126 CJA 2003 allows exclusion of superfluous hearsay.
criminalPractice.exp: Discretion to exclude to avoid waste of time.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Foreman' delivers the jury's verdict.
criminalPractice.exp: Juror elected to speak for the group.

criminalPractice.q: Jury Bailiffs swear an oath to keep the jury private.
criminalPractice.exp: Procedure when jury retires.

criminalPractice.q: s.9 CJA 1967 allows agreed statements to be read.
criminalPractice.exp: Written evidence procedure.

criminalPractice.q: s.10 CJA 1967 allows formal admissions.
criminalPractice.exp: Facts agreed between parties.

criminalPractice.q: A Newton hearing is required if the difference in facts is immaterial to the sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: A Newton hearing is only held if the factual dispute would make a material difference to the sentence.

criminalPractice.q: If a defendant loses a Newton hearing, their credit for a guilty plea is usually halved.
criminalPractice.exp: The reduction is normally halved because court time and witnesses were used to determine facts.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can commit an offender to the Crown Court for sentence if their powers are insufficient.
criminalPractice.exp: s.14 Sentencing Act 2020; allows committal if the offence warrants greater punishment.

criminalPractice.q: The minimum sentence for a third Class A drug trafficking offence is 5 years.
criminalPractice.exp: s.313 Sentencing Act 2020; the minimum sentence is 7 years (unless unjust).

criminalPractice.q: The minimum sentence for a third domestic burglary is 3 years.
criminalPractice.exp: s.314 Sentencing Act 2020; applies to third domestic burglary conviction.

criminalPractice.q: A Crown Court judge can suspend a sentence of up to 3 years.
criminalPractice.exp: A sentence can only be suspended if the custodial term is between 14 days and 2 years.

criminalPractice.q: The operational period of a suspended sentence must be between 6 months and 2 years.
criminalPractice.exp: The period during which the sentence is suspended is statutorily limited.

criminalPractice.q: A court can defer a sentence for up to 12 months.
criminalPractice.exp: Sentence can be deferred for up to 6 months to allow the offender to prove conduct.

criminalPractice.q: A Goodyear indication in the Crown Court binds the judge if the defendant pleads guilty.
criminalPractice.exp: R v Goodyear; the indication of maximum sentence is binding if the plea is entered.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can give a specific indication of sentence length before a plea.
criminalPractice.exp: Magistrates can only indicate whether the sentence will be custodial or non-custodial.

criminalPractice.q: The custody threshold requires that neither a fine nor community sentence can be justified.
criminalPractice.exp: s.230 Sentencing Act 2020; custody is a last resort.

criminalPractice.q: A Community Order can last for a maximum of 2 years.
criminalPractice.exp: The maximum duration of a Community Order is 3 years.

criminalPractice.q: Unpaid work requirements must be between 40 and 300 hours.
criminalPractice.exp: Statutory range for unpaid work requirements.

criminalPractice.q: A curfew requirement can be imposed for up to 20 hours a day.
criminalPractice.exp: Curfew limits are 2-16 hours in any 24-hour period.

criminalPractice.q: A guilty plea on the day of trial attracts a maximum reduction of one-third.
criminalPractice.exp: Guilty plea on the day of trial attracts a maximum reduction of one-tenth (1/10).

criminalPractice.q: A prisoner serving an Extended Determinate Sentence (EDS) is automatically released at the halfway point.
criminalPractice.exp: They are eligible to apply for parole at the two-thirds point of the custodial term.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Slip Rule' allows a judge to vary a sentence within 56 days.
criminalPractice.exp: s.385 Sentencing Act 2020; to correct errors in sentencing.

criminalPractice.q: Breach of a Community Order can result in a fine of up to £2,500.
criminalPractice.exp: Schedule 10 SA 2020; fine is one option for breach.

criminalPractice.q: Consecutive sentences are generally used for offences arising from the same incident.
criminalPractice.exp: Concurrent sentences are used for the same incident; consecutive for separate events.

criminalPractice.q: A pre-sentence report is mandatory before passing a custodial sentence (unless unnecessary).
criminalPractice.exp: s.30 Sentencing Act 2020; court must obtain a report unless it considers it unnecessary.

criminalPractice.q: Time spent on qualifying electronically monitored curfew counts towards a custodial sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: Credit is given for half a day for each day on qualifying curfew (9+ hours).

criminalPractice.q: The general limit for a single offence in the Magistrates' Court is 6 months.
criminalPractice.exp: s.224 SA 2020; though briefly increased to 12 months, it reverted to 6 months.

criminalPractice.q: A court must activate a suspended sentence upon breach unless it is unjust.
criminalPractice.exp: Presumption of activation in whole or part upon breach.

criminalPractice.q: Absolute discharge means the conviction is not recorded.
criminalPractice.exp: The conviction stands, but no punishment is imposed.

criminalPractice.q: A fine can be combined with a conditional discharge for the same offence.
criminalPractice.exp: A discharge cannot be combined with a fine for the same offence.

criminalPractice.q: The Sentencing Code is contained in the Sentencing Act 2020.
criminalPractice.exp: Consolidated sentencing legislation.

criminalPractice.q: s.57 SA 2020 sets out the purposes of sentencing.
criminalPractice.exp: Punishment, reduction of crime, reform, protection, reparation.

criminalPractice.q: Culpability refers to the harm caused to the victim.
criminalPractice.exp: Culpability refers to the offender's blameworthiness; Harm refers to the impact.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Category 1' offence represents the lowest seriousness.
criminalPractice.exp: Category 1 is the highest seriousness (High Culpability/High Harm).

criminalPractice.q: Aggravating factors increase the severity of the sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., previous convictions, use of a weapon.

criminalPractice.q: Mitigating factors reduce the severity of the sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., remorse, lack of previous convictions.

criminalPractice.q: Previous convictions are a statutory aggravating factor.
criminalPractice.exp: s.65 Sentencing Act 2020.

criminalPractice.q: Remorse is a mitigating factor.
criminalPractice.exp: Listed in sentencing guidelines.

criminalPractice.q: Totality involves ensuring the overall sentence is just and proportionate.
criminalPractice.exp: Sentencing principle for multiple offences.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Concurrent' sentence runs at the same time as another.
criminalPractice.exp: Total time served is the length of the longest sentence.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Consecutive' sentence adds to the length of another.
criminalPractice.exp: Sentences run one after the other.

criminalPractice.q: An 'Absolute Discharge' involves no penalty.
criminalPractice.exp: Finding of guilt but no punishment.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Conditional Discharge' requires the offender not to reoffend for a set period.
criminalPractice.exp: If they reoffend, they are resentenced for the original offence.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Suspended Sentence' is a custodial sentence served in the community.
criminalPractice.exp: Prison term is suspended on conditions.

criminalPractice.q: Murder carries a mandatory life sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: Schedule 21 SA 2020 sets minimum terms.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Whole Life Order' means the offender is never released.
criminalPractice.exp: Reserved for the most serious murders.

criminalPractice.q: Sentencing Guidelines must be followed unless contrary to the interests of justice.
criminalPractice.exp: s.59 Sentencing Act 2020.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Victim Impact Statement' details the effect of the crime on the victim.
criminalPractice.exp: Read to the court before sentencing.

criminalPractice.q: The maximum reduction for a guilty plea at the first stage is one-third.
criminalPractice.exp: Sentencing Council Guidelines on Guilty Pleas.

criminalPractice.q: 'EDS' stands for Extended Determinate Sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: Custodial term plus extended licence for dangerous offenders.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Bind Over' requires a person to keep the peace.
criminalPractice.exp: Forfeit a sum of money if breached.

criminalPractice.q: Fines are the most common criminal sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: Used for approx 80% of offences.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Surcharge' is a mandatory payment to fund victim services.
criminalPractice.exp: Imposed alongside other sentences.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Newton Hearing' is held without a jury.
criminalPractice.exp: The judge (or magistrates) is the arbiter of fact.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Custody Threshold' is the test for imposing imprisonment.
criminalPractice.exp: Offence must be 'so serious'.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can use s.142 MCA 1980 to increase a sentence.
criminalPractice.exp: s.142 MCA 1980; exceptionally, e.g., if the court was misled by the defendant.

criminalPractice.q: The prosecution can appeal a Magistrates' acquittal to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.108 MCA 1980; prosecution cannot appeal to Crown Court, only by Case Stated/JR.

criminalPractice.q: The Crown Court can increase a sentence on appeal from the Magistrates.
criminalPractice.exp: s.48 Senior Courts Act 1981; sentence is 'at large' up to the Magistrates' limit.

criminalPractice.q: An appeal by way of Case Stated involves a re-hearing of the evidence.
criminalPractice.exp: Case Stated deals with errors of law/jurisdiction based on agreed facts; no evidence is heard.

criminalPractice.q: The time limit for an appeal by way of Case Stated is 21 days.
criminalPractice.exp: s.111 MCA 1980; strictly applied time limit.

criminalPractice.q: An application for Judicial Review must be made within 3 months.
criminalPractice.exp: Must be made 'promptly' and in any event within 3 months.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant alleging bias by Magistrates should appeal to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Ex p Rowlands; allegations of unfairness/bias should go to Judicial Review.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can grant bail pending an appeal to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.113 MCA 1980; bail pending appeal is available.

criminalPractice.q: The Crown Court Slip Rule (s.385) applies to errors of law in conviction.
criminalPractice.exp: s.385 Sentencing Act 2020; applies to sentences/orders, not convictions.

criminalPractice.q: The Crown Court Slip Rule time limit is 28 days.
criminalPractice.exp: s.385 Sentencing Act 2020; the limit is 56 days.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant pleading guilty in the Crown Court cannot appeal the conviction.
criminalPractice.exp: Can appeal if the plea was a nullity (e.g., erroneous legal ruling or undue pressure).

criminalPractice.q: Notice of Appeal to the Court of Appeal must be served within 28 days.
criminalPractice.exp: s.18 Criminal Appeal Act 1968; 28 days from conviction or sentence.

criminalPractice.q: If the Single Judge refuses leave, the appellant has 14 days to renew.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR; the renewal period is 10 business days.

criminalPractice.q: The Court of Appeal can increase a sentence on an appeal by the defendant.
criminalPractice.exp: s.11(3) CAA 1968; appellant cannot be dealt with more severely than the court below.

criminalPractice.q: The Attorney General can refer an unduly lenient sentence for Theft.
criminalPractice.exp: CJA 1988; only for indictable-only or specified either-way offences (Theft is not specified).

criminalPractice.q: An Attorney General's Reference on a point of law overturns the acquittal.
criminalPractice.exp: s.36 CJA 1972; clarifies the law but the acquittal stands.

criminalPractice.q: A Loss of Time order can be made by the Single Judge.
criminalPractice.exp: s.29 CAA 1968; though usually made by the full court on renewal.

criminalPractice.q: Jurors can be compelled to give evidence to the Court of Appeal.
criminalPractice.exp: s.23 CAA 1968; wide power to receive fresh evidence.

criminalPractice.q: Prosecution appeal against a terminatory ruling requires an acquittal agreement.
criminalPractice.exp: s.58 CJA 2003; prosecution must agree to acquittal if appeal fails/abandoned.

criminalPractice.q: The CCRC can refer a case only if there is new evidence/argument.
criminalPractice.exp: Criminal Appeal Act 1995; usually requires something not previously raised.

criminalPractice.q: An appeal from the High Court (Case Stated) goes to the Court of Appeal.
criminalPractice.exp: Administration of Justice Act 1960; leapfrogs to the Supreme Court.

criminalPractice.q: A defendant who pleaded guilty in Magistrates' can appeal conviction to Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.108 MCA 1980; guilty plea restricts appeal to sentence only (unless equivocal).

criminalPractice.q: A prosecution appeal against a terminatory ruling must be expedited.
criminalPractice.exp: s.59 CJA 2003; to prevent jury discharge where possible.

criminalPractice.q: The Court of Appeal can order a retrial if a conviction is quashed.
criminalPractice.exp: s.7 CAA 1968; if the interests of justice so require.

criminalPractice.q: Magistrates can refuse to state a case if they consider it frivolous.
criminalPractice.exp: s.111 MCA 1980; 'frivolous' in the legal sense (futile/vexatious).

criminalPractice.q: s.142 MCA 1980 is the power to rectify mistakes.
criminalPractice.exp: Magistrates' power to set aside conviction/vary sentence.

criminalPractice.q: s.108 MCA 1980 provides the right of appeal to the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Standard appeal route from Magistrates.

criminalPractice.q: Appeal by 'Case Stated' is to the High Court.
criminalPractice.exp: s.111 MCA 1980; Divisional Court of QBD.

criminalPractice.q: Judicial Review deals with procedural irregularity.
criminalPractice.exp: e.g., breach of natural justice, bias.

criminalPractice.q: An appeal to the Crown Court is a 're-hearing'.
criminalPractice.exp: Evidence is heard afresh.

criminalPractice.q: Notice of Appeal to Crown Court is 15 business days.
criminalPractice.exp: CrimPR Part 34.

criminalPractice.q: s.385 Sentencing Act 2020 is the Crown Court Slip Rule.
criminalPractice.exp: Power to correct sentences.

criminalPractice.q: CAA 1968 stands for Criminal Appeal Act 1968.
criminalPractice.exp: Primary statute for the Court of Appeal.

criminalPractice.q: A 'Single Judge' considers leave to appeal on paper.
criminalPractice.exp: s.31 CAA 1968 procedure.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Registrar' manages criminal appeals.
criminalPractice.exp: Receives forms, orders transcripts.

criminalPractice.q: 'Perfecting grounds' involves adding transcript references.

criminalPractice.q: A 13-year-old can receive a DTO if they are a persistent offender.

criminalPractice.q: Reporting restrictions apply automatically in the Adult Magistrates' Court for youths.

criminalPractice.q: A youth jointly charged with an adult has their first hearing in the Youth Court.
criminalPractice.exp: First hearing takes place in the Adult Magistrates' Court.

criminalPractice.q: If an adult co-defendant pleads guilty, the youth must be remitted to the Youth Court for trial.
criminalPractice.exp: Unless the youth is charged with a homicide or grave crime requiring Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: A Referral Order is mandatory for a first-time offender pleading guilty to an imprisonable offence.
criminalPractice.exp: Unless the sentence is fixed by law or custody/discharge is appropriate.

criminalPractice.q: A court can impose a Referral Order if it intends to give an absolute discharge.
criminalPractice.exp: A Referral Order cannot be given if an absolute or conditional discharge is justified.

criminalPractice.q: Parents must be required to attend court if the accused is under 16.

criminalPractice.q: The 'Grave Crimes' provisions apply to offences carrying 10 years imprisonment for an adult.
criminalPractice.exp: s.249 SA 2020; applies to offences carrying 14 years or more.

criminalPractice.q: A youth can elect trial by jury for an either-way offence.
criminalPractice.exp: A youth has no right of election; mode of trial is determined by the court.

criminalPractice.q: The Youth Court can sentence a youth to 4 years detention for a grave crime.
criminalPractice.exp: Youth Court limit is 24 months DTO; longer sentences require committal to Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: The Crown Court must remit a convicted youth to the Youth Court for sentence.

criminalPractice.q: A Referral Order can be imposed for a minimum of 1 month.

criminalPractice.q: The police can authorise a Youth Caution for an indictable-only offence.

criminalPractice.q: A youth charged with a summary-only offence cannot be tried in the Crown Court.
criminalPractice.exp: Summary offences remain in the Magistrates/Youth Court unless s.40 applies (rare).

criminalPractice.q: Intensive Supervision and Surveillance (ISS) is available for all youths.
criminalPractice.exp: If under 15, they must be a persistent offender.

criminalPractice.q: A 'persistent young offender' is defined by statute.

criminalPractice.q: If a youth and adult are jointly charged, the youth is always tried in the Crown Court.

criminalPractice.q: The custody officer can detain a youth in police custody if secure accommodation is expensive.

criminalPractice.exp: A substantial gap militates in favour of separate trials.

willsAdmin.q: Can you act where there is a significant risk of an own interest conflict?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 6.1 prohibits acting where there is an own interest conflict or significant risk thereof, with no exceptions.

willsAdmin.q: Does the duty of confidentiality take precedence over the duty of disclosure where they conflict?
willsAdmin.exp: Where duties conflict, confidentiality (CCS 6.3) takes precedence over disclosure (CCS 6.4) unless an exception applies.

willsAdmin.q: Is money received for a disbursement you have already paid considered client money?
willsAdmin.exp: Money received for paid disbursements is non-client money; only money for unpaid disbursements is client money (Rule 2.1(d) SRA Accounts Rules).

willsAdmin.q: Can you act for two clients with adverse interests if they have a substantially common interest?
willsAdmin.exp: You may act under the 'substantially common interest' exception if conditions in CCS 6.2(a) and (i)-(iii) are met.

willsAdmin.q: Is treating a man less favourably regarding pregnancy benefits considered direct discrimination?
willsAdmin.exp: Under s.13(6)(b) Equality Act 2010, special treatment afforded to women in connection with pregnancy is not discrimination against men.

willsAdmin.q: Must you cease acting if a client instructs you to mislead the court?
willsAdmin.exp: You must uphold the rule of law and proper administration of justice (Principle 1) and not mislead the court (CCS 1.4).

willsAdmin.q: Are you required to pay client money into a client account within 24 hours?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 2.3 SRA Accounts Rules requires client money to be paid in 'promptly', not within a specific fixed timeframe like 24 hours.

willsAdmin.q: Can you withdraw client money for a client if they have insufficient funds in the account?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 5.3 SRA Accounts Rules prohibits withdrawing funds unless sufficient funds are held for that specific client.

willsAdmin.q: Is a firm manager personally responsible for the firm's compliance with Accounts Rules?
willsAdmin.exp: Managers are jointly and severally responsible for compliance by the authorised body and its employees (Rule 1.2 SRA Accounts Rules).

willsAdmin.q: Does the duty to make reasonable adjustments for disabled persons only arise upon request?
willsAdmin.exp: The duty is anticipatory; service providers must think in advance about what disabled people might reasonably need (Equality Act 2010).

willsAdmin.q: Can you disclose confidential information if you believe a child is in danger?
willsAdmin.exp: This is a recognized exception to the duty of confidentiality where there are grounds to believe a child's health is in danger.

willsAdmin.q: Is money received on account of costs generally considered client money?
willsAdmin.exp: Money received on account of costs relates to regulated services and is client money under Rule 2.1(a) SRA Accounts Rules.

willsAdmin.q: Must a client care letter always be sent to comply with CCS requirements?
willsAdmin.exp: A letter is not mandatory, though providing certain information in writing is required; the letter is the standard method of compliance.

willsAdmin.q: Can you act against a former client if you hold material confidential information about them?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 6.5 prohibits acting unless effective measures protect the information or the former client gives informed consent.

willsAdmin.q: Is a firm exempt from an accountant's report if the average client balance is £15,000?
willsAdmin.exp: The exemption applies if the average balance does not exceed £10,000 (and max balance £250,000) (Rule 12.2 SRA Accounts Rules).

willsAdmin.q: Must you terminate a retainer if you cannot obtain clear instructions from the client?
willsAdmin.exp: Inability to obtain clear instructions is a good reason to terminate the retainer.

willsAdmin.q: Can you transfer money from a client account to pay your bill before sending the bill?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 4.3 requires you to give a bill or written notification of costs before transferring client money to pay those costs.

willsAdmin.q: Is the 'competing for the same objective' conflict exception common in practice?
willsAdmin.exp: This exception (CCS 6.2(b)) is very rare and usually applies only to sophisticated clients in auctions or tenders.

willsAdmin.q: Does the duty of disclosure extend to information known only by your colleagues?
willsAdmin.exp: The duty under CCS 6.4 is limited to information of which the individual solicitor has personal knowledge.

willsAdmin.q: Can you act for a client if your personal political views affect your relationship?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 1.1 prohibits unfairly discriminating by allowing personal views to affect professional relationships.

willsAdmin.q: Is a cheque payable to the client considered 'client money' under the Accounts Rules?
willsAdmin.exp: A cheque payable to the client cannot be banked in the client account and does not fall within the Rule 2.1 definition.

willsAdmin.q: Must you repay money improperly withdrawn from a client account immediately?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 6.1 SRA Accounts Rules requires immediate replacement of any money improperly withheld or withdrawn.

willsAdmin.q: Is victimisation treating someone less favourably because they made a discrimination allegation?
willsAdmin.exp: Victimisation is subjecting B to detriment because B has done a protected act, such as alleging a contravention of the Equality Act (s.27).

willsAdmin.q: Can a firm use a client account to provide banking facilities to a client?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 3.3 SRA Accounts Rules prohibits using a client account to provide banking facilities to clients or third parties.

willsAdmin.q: Is failing to justify a PCP that disadvantages a protected group indirect discrimination?
willsAdmin.exp: Indirect discrimination occurs if a PCP disadvantages a protected group and cannot be shown to be a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim (s.19).

willsAdmin.q: Is 'acting in the best interests of your employer' an SRA Principle?
willsAdmin.exp: This is not one of the seven SRA Principles; public interest principles take priority over employer interests.

willsAdmin.q: Are there seven SRA Principles?
willsAdmin.exp: The SRA Standards and Regulations 2019 list exactly seven Principles.

willsAdmin.q: Is 'Measles' a protected characteristic under the Equality Act 2010?
willsAdmin.exp: Measles is not a protected characteristic; Disability, Race, Sex, etc., are listed in the Equality Act 2010.

willsAdmin.q: Does CCS 6.3 apply to former clients?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 6.3 requires you to keep the affairs of current and former clients confidential.

willsAdmin.q: Is money received for unpaid professional fees considered client money?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 2.1(d) defines money received for fees prior to the delivery of a bill as client money.

willsAdmin.q: Must a client account include the word 'client' in its name?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 3.2 SRA Accounts Rules requires the account name to include the authorised body's name and the word 'client'.

willsAdmin.q: Is 'harassment' one of the prohibited conducts under the Equality Act 2010?
willsAdmin.exp: The Act prohibits Direct/Indirect discrimination, Harassment, and Victimisation.

willsAdmin.q: Must you maintain accounting records for at least 6 years?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 13.1 SRA Accounts Rules requires accounting records to be stored securely and retained for at least six years.

willsAdmin.q: Is an accountant's report required if all client money comes from the Legal Aid Agency?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 12.2(a) provides an exemption if all client money is received from the Legal Aid Agency.

willsAdmin.q: Does 'CDD' stand for Client Due Diligence?
willsAdmin.exp: In the context of the Money Laundering Regulations, CDD stands for Customer Due Diligence.

willsAdmin.q: Does a 'mixed payment' include both client and non-client money?
willsAdmin.exp: A mixed payment is defined in the SRA Glossary as a payment that includes both client money and non-client money.

willsAdmin.q: Must you account to clients for a fair sum of interest on client money?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 7.1 SRA Accounts Rules requires accounting for a fair sum of interest on client money held.

willsAdmin.q: Is 'Integrity' the same as 'Honesty' under the SRA Principles?
willsAdmin.exp: Integrity is broader than honesty; you can lack integrity without being dishonest (e.g., being reckless).

willsAdmin.q: Does CCS 6.4 relate to the duty of disclosure?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 6.4 requires making the client aware of all material information of which you have knowledge.

willsAdmin.q: Is age a protected characteristic under the Equality Act 2010?
willsAdmin.exp: Age is listed as a protected characteristic in the Equality Act 2010.

willsAdmin.q: Can you use a client account to hold money for a third party without providing regulated services?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 3.3 prohibits using client accounts as a banking facility; transactions must relate to regulated services.

willsAdmin.q: Is 'Promptly' defined as 3 days in the SRA Accounts Rules?
willsAdmin.exp: There is no specific definition of 'promptly' in the SRA Accounts Rules.

willsAdmin.q: Do SRA Principles apply to a solicitor's private life?
willsAdmin.exp: The Principles apply to legal professionals in their personal as well as their professional lives.

willsAdmin.q: Is money held as a trustee considered client money?
willsAdmin.exp: Rule 2.1(c) defines money held as a trustee or holder of a specified office as client money.

willsAdmin.q: Does 'CCS' stand for Code of Conduct for Solicitors?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS is the shorthand for the SRA Code of Conduct for Solicitors, RELs and RFLs.

willsAdmin.q: Can a firm act where there is an own interest conflict?
willsAdmin.exp: CCS 6.1 imposes a strict prohibition on acting where there is an own interest conflict.

willsAdmin.q: Is the 'Code of Conduct for Firms' abbreviated as CCF?
willsAdmin.exp: CCF is the standard abbreviation for the SRA Code of Conduct for Firms.

willsAdmin.q: Must a conflict check include the names of directors of a corporate client?
willsAdmin.exp: Conflict checks should include directors of the client and counterparty to identify previous relationships.

willsAdmin.q: Does the duty of confidentiality end when a client dies?
willsAdmin.exp: The duty of confidentiality continues to apply after a client's death.

willsAdmin.q: Is a 'fixed fee' agreement one where costs are capped?
willsAdmin.exp: A fixed fee is a set amount regardless of time; a capped fee records time but will not exceed a limit.

willsAdmin.q: Does the succession estate include property passing by survivorship?
willsAdmin.exp: Property passing by survivorship, such as joint tenancies, bypasses the will/intestacy and is excluded from the succession estate.

willsAdmin.q: Is a discretionary pension lump sum part of the succession estate?
willsAdmin.exp: Discretionary pension benefits do not form part of the deceased's estate for distribution purposes as payment is at the trustees' discretion.

willsAdmin.q: Does a life policy written in trust for a third party pass into the succession estate?
willsAdmin.exp: The proceeds belong to the beneficiaries nominated in the trust and vest on the insured's death, bypassing the succession estate.

willsAdmin.q: Does a donatio mortis causa (DMC) form part of the succession estate?
willsAdmin.exp: A valid DMC gift passes directly to the donee upon death and does not form part of the succession estate administered by PRs.

willsAdmin.q: If a will fails to dispose of the residue, do the intestacy rules apply to it?
willsAdmin.exp: Partial intestacy occurs when a valid will fails to dispose of the entire estate, so intestacy rules apply to the undisposed residue.

willsAdmin.q: Does a spouse need to survive the intestate by 28 days to inherit?
willsAdmin.exp: Under s.46(2A) AEA 1925, a spouse must survive the intestate by 28 days to take a beneficial interest.

willsAdmin.q: Do issue take the statutory legacy on intestacy?
