public_law_2.q: A 'Hybrid' public authority is liable under s.6 HRA for all its acts.
public_law_2.exp: Only liable in respect of its 'public functions' (s.6(3)(b) & s.6(5) HRA).

public_law_2.q: Aston Cantlow established that 'Core' public authorities are liable for all acts.
public_law_2.exp: Government departments/Police are core authorities.

public_law_2.q: The limitation period for an HRA claim is 1 year.
public_law_2.exp: s.7(5) HRA 1998 (unless the court extends for equity).

public_law_2.q: Damages are the primary remedy for HRA breaches.
public_law_2.exp: Damages are discretionary and a last resort (s.8 HRA); 'Just Satisfaction'.

public_law_2.q: Article 5 ECHR (Liberty) is an absolute right.
public_law_2.exp: Limited right; allows for lawful arrest/detention under specific subsections.

public_law_2.q: Article 3 ECHR (Torture) is a qualified right.
public_law_2.exp: Absolute right; never justifiable (Ireland v UK).

public_law_2.q: Proportionality is the test used for Qualified Rights (e.g., Art 8, 10, 11).
public_law_2.exp: Bank Mellat / Huang tests for proportionality.

public_law_2.q: Legitimate Expectation can be substantive as well as procedural.
public_law_2.exp: R v North and East Devon Health Authority, ex p Coughlan.

public_law_2.q: Judicial Review remedies are available as of right.
public_law_2.exp: They are discretionary; court may refuse even if a ground is made out.

public_law_2.q: A 'quashing order' substitutes the court's decision for the public body's.
public_law_2.exp: It voids the decision and usually remits it back to the body to decide again lawfully.

public_law_2.q: Errors of law on the face of the record are always amenable to Judicial Review.
public_law_2.exp: Anisminic Ltd v Foreign Compensation Commission.

public_law_2.q: The 'Anxious Scrutiny' test is used when human rights are at stake (pre-HRA context).
public_law_2.exp: R v Ministry of Defence, ex p Smith; requires more than mere reasonableness.

public_law_2.q: The 'Super-Wednesbury' standard applies to macro-economic policy decisions.
public_law_2.exp: R v Nottinghamshire CC; courts are very reluctant to intervene.

public_law_2.q: It is unlawful for a decision-maker to follow a secret, unpublished policy.
public_law_2.exp: R (Lumba) v Secretary of State for the Home Department.

public_law_2.q: A decision-maker has a duty to apply their own published policy.
public_law_2.exp: Mandalia v Home Secretary; failure to do so is unfair.

public_law_2.q: An ultra vires promise by a public authority creates a binding legitimate expectation.
public_law_2.exp: R v Dept for Education, ex p Begbie; power cannot be extended by estoppel.

public_law_2.q: Detrimental reliance is a strict requirement for Legitimate Expectation.
public_law_2.exp: R (Bibi) v Newham LBC; reliance is relevant but not strictly essential.

public_law_2.q: Forfeiture cases (e.g., losing a licence) require the highest standard of fairness.
public_law_2.exp: McInnes v Onslow-Fane; compared to mere application cases.

public_law_2.q: Councillors are disqualified if they have a 'predisposition' towards a decision.
public_law_2.exp: Lewis v Redcar; Predisposition is allowed, 'Predetermination' (closed mind) is not.

public_law_2.q: The 'fair-minded observer' in bias cases is assumed to be unduly suspicious.
public_law_2.exp: Helow v Home Secretary; observer is informed but not paranoid.

public_law_2.q: An individual has a right to know the case against them.
public_law_2.exp: Kanda v Government of Malaya; core principle of natural justice.

public_law_2.q: There is a general common law duty to give reasons for all administrative decisions.
public_law_2.exp: R v Home Secretary, ex p Doody; duty arises only if fairness demands it.

public_law_2.q: An oral hearing is required if the decision turns on the credibility of the applicant.
public_law_2.exp: R (Osborn) v Parole Board.

public_law_2.q: Prisoners have an absolute right to legal representation in disciplinary hearings.
public_law_2.exp: Hone v Maze Prison Visitors; discretionary based on seriousness/complexity.

public_law_2.q: Consultation is only lawful if done at a formative stage of proposals.
public_law_2.exp: First Gunning Principle (R v Brent LBC, ex p Gunning).

public_law_2.q: A public body must consult on rejected options as well as the preferred one.
public_law_2.exp: R (Moseley) v Haringey LBC; fairness requires context for the consultation.

public_law_2.q: Failure to comply with a statutory procedure always renders the decision void.
public_law_2.exp: R v Soneji; courts look at the intended consequences of non-compliance.

public_law_2.q: Substantial compliance with a procedural requirement may be sufficient.
public_law_2.exp: Coney v Choyce; rigid adherence not always required if purpose achieved.

public_law_2.q: A Minister can lawfully surrender their decision-making power to a trade union.
public_law_2.exp: Lavender v Minister of Housing; unlawful delegation (acting under dictation).

public_law_2.q: It is unlawful for a decision-maker to surrender to a foreign threat.
public_law_2.exp: R (Corner House Research) v SFO; rule of law prohibits surrendering to threats (though SFO had discretion here).

public_law_2.q: Punishing a rugby club for its players' views is an irrational use of power.
public_law_2.exp: Wheeler v Leicester City Council; improper purpose/irrationality.

public_law_2.q: The High Court can substitute its own decision for that of a public body in Judicial Review.
public_law_2.exp: Under s.31(5A) Senior Courts Act 1981, usually only if there is 'no other decision' possible; otherwise remitted.

public_law_2.q: A Declaration is a coercive remedy that forces a public body to act.
public_law_2.exp: Declarations state the legal position but are not coercive; Mandatory Orders are coercive.

public_law_2.q: Under s.31(2A) SCA 1981, relief must be refused if the outcome would not be substantially different.
public_law_2.exp: The 'highly likely' test makes refusal mandatory unless there are exceptional public interest reasons.

public_law_2.q: Section 12 Public Order Act 1986 applies to static assemblies.
public_law_2.exp: Section 12 applies to public processions; Section 14 applies to public assemblies.

public_law_2.q: A 'public assembly' under POA 1986 requires 20 or more persons.
public_law_2.exp: Amended by Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 to '2 or more persons' (s.16).

public_law_2.q: Police can ban a procession under s.13 POA 1986 without Home Secretary consent.
public_law_2.exp: Chief Constable applies to Council/Home Sec; Commissioner applies to Home Sec.

public_law_2.q: A 'breach of the peace' can occur in private premises.
public_law_2.exp: R v Howell; can occur wherever harm is done or threatened.

public_law_2.q: Police have a power of arrest for anticipated breach of the peace.
public_law_2.exp: R v Howell; if a breach is imminent.

public_law_2.q: Conditions on a procession can only be imposed by the most senior officer present at the scene.
public_law_2.exp: s.12(2)(b) POA 1986; or by the Chief Officer in advance.

public_law_2.q: 'Serious disruption to the life of the community' is a ground for imposing conditions.
The 'kettling' (containment) of protestors is a deprivation of liberty under Article 5 ECHR.
public_law_2.exp: Austin v UK; judged as a restriction on movement if proportionate and for short duration.

public_law_2.q: Organisers of a procession must give 6 clear days' notice.
Spontaneous processions are exempt from the notice requirement.
public_law_2.exp: s.11(1) POA 1986; notice required unless not reasonably practicable.

public_law_2.q: The police can ban a static assembly under s.14 POA 1986.
public_law_2.exp: Police can only impose conditions on assemblies; s.13 bans apply only to processions.

public_law_2.q: Actions for damages under the HRA must be brought within 3 months.
public_law_2.exp: 1 year limitation period for HRA s.7 claims (not judicial review JR time limits).

public_law_2.q: The 'Laporte' case established that police must reasonably believe a breach of peace is imminent.
public_law_2.exp: R (Laporte) v Chief Constable of Gloucestershire; preventing travel was unlawful premature intervention.

public_law_2.q: Trespassory assemblies can be banned under s.14A POA 1986.
public_law_2.exp: Chief Officer can apply for an order prohibiting trespassory assemblies.

public_law_2.q: Section 5 POA 1986 (Harassment, Alarm, Distress) requires intent.
public_law_2.exp: Intent OR awareness that behaviour may be threatening/abusive/insulting (s.6(4)).

public_law_2.q: Insulting words were removed from Section 5 POA 1986.
public_law_2.exp: Crime and Courts Act 2013 removed 'insulting' to protect free speech.

public_law_2.q: The 'reasonable belief' of the police officer imposing conditions is subjective.
public_law_2.exp: It is subject to objective judicial review (though deference is shown to operational decisions).

public_law_2.q: Damages in Judicial Review are awarded for purely procedural errors.
public_law_2.exp: No damages for maladministration alone; requires a recognized tort or HRA breach.

public_law_2.q: A Prohibiting Order prevents a public body from acting unlawfully in the future.
public_law_2.exp: Similar to a Quashing Order but prospective.

public_law_2.q: Article 11 ECHR protects the right to a peaceful assembly.
public_law_2.exp: Freedom of assembly and association.

public_law_2.q: Any restriction on Article 11 rights must be 'prescribed by law'.
public_law_2.exp: Article 11(2); restrictions must be lawful, necessary, and proportionate.

public_law_2.q: The 'margin of appreciation' applies in domestic UK courts.
public_law_2.exp: It is an international doctrine for the ECtHR; domestic courts use 'discretionary area of judgment'.

public_law_2.q: The 'Victim Test' under s.7 HRA is identical to 'Sufficient Interest' in Judicial Review.
public_law_2.exp: Victim test (Art 34 ECHR) is narrower; applicant must be directly affected.

public_law_2.q: Article 34 ECHR prevents NGOs from being 'victims' unless directly affected.
public_law_2.exp: Unlike JR, public interest groups cannot claim unless they are the victim of the violation.

public_law_2.q: A 'Remedial Order' under s.10 HRA is used to amend legislation incompatible with the ECHR.
public_law_2.exp: A fast-track 'Henry VIII' power for Ministers to amend primary legislation.

public_law_2.q: Article 2 ECHR (Life) applies to cases of medical negligence in NHS hospitals.
public_law_2.exp: Powell v UK; generally Art 2 is not engaged unless there is a systemic failure.

public_law_2.q: Article 2 includes a 'right to die'.
public_law_2.exp: Pretty v UK; Article 2 protects life, it does not confer a right to end it.

public_law_2.q: The state has a positive obligation to protect life from real and immediate risks.
public_law_2.exp: Osman v UK; the 'Osman warning' duty.

public_law_2.q: Article 5(1)(c) permits detention for 'preventive' purposes without specific suspicion.
public_law_2.exp: Ostendorf v Germany; detention must be linked to suspicion of an offence or preventing a specific offence.

public_law_2.q: Article 6 (Fair Trial) applies to employment disputes for civil servants.
public_law_2.exp: Vilho Eskelinen v Finland; unless expressly excluded by national law with objective justification.

public_law_2.q: Hearsay evidence is automatically a breach of Article 6 in criminal trials.
public_law_2.exp: Al-Khawaja and Tahery v UK; permissible if there are sufficient counterbalancing factors.

public_law_2.q: Article 8 (Privacy) protects physical and psychological integrity.
public_law_2.exp: Pretty v UK; expansive interpretation of 'private life'.

public_law_2.q: Retention of DNA profiles of unconvicted persons breaches Article 8.
public_law_2.exp: S and Marper v UK; blanket retention is disproportionate.

public_law_2.q: Article 10 (Expression) protects the right to access government information.
public_law_2.exp: Kennedy v Charity Commission; Art 10 is not a general Freedom of Information act.

public_law_2.q: Political speech receives the highest level of protection under Article 10.
public_law_2.exp: Lingens v Austria; narrow margin of appreciation for restrictions.

public_law_2.q: Article 11 imposes a positive obligation on the state to protect demonstrations.
public_law_2.exp: Plattform 'Ärzte für das Leben' v Austria; protect from counter-demonstrators.

public_law_2.q: A 'Parochial Church Council' is a core public authority under s.6 HRA.
public_law_2.exp: Aston Cantlow; it is a hybrid authority (not core because of religious nature).

public_law_2.q: Housing Associations are always private bodies for HRA purposes.
public_law_2.exp: Weaver v London and Quadrant Housing Trust; they are hybrid authorities when performing public functions.

public_law_2.q: In 'Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza', the court used s.3 HRA to interpret 'spouse' to include same-sex partners.
public_law_2.exp: A leading example of strong s.3 interpretation to achieve compatibility.

public_law_2.q: The 'mirror principle' prevents UK courts from granting more rights than Strasbourg.
public_law_2.exp: R (Ullah) sets a 'floor' not a 'ceiling'; UK courts can go further (Rabone).

public_law_2.q: A statement of incompatibility under s.19 HRA prevents a Bill from becoming law.
public_law_2.exp: Parliament can proceed with the Bill regardless (political constraint only).

public_law_2.q: Voluntary mental health patients are owed an operational duty under Article 2 to prevent suicide.
public_law_2.exp: Rabone v Pennine Care NHS Trust; duty exists even if not detained under MHA.

public_law_2.q: Control orders imposing 18-hour curfews constituted a deprivation of liberty (Art 5).
public_law_2.exp: Secretary of State for the Home Department v JJ; breach of Art 5.

public_law_2.q: The 'Living Instrument' doctrine allows the ECHR to be interpreted in light of modern standards.
public_law_2.exp: Tyrer v UK; ECHR is not static.

public_law_2.q: Article 1 of the First Protocol (A1P1) protects the right to property.
public_law_2.exp: Peaceful enjoyment of possessions.

public_law_2.q: Deprivation of property under A1P1 always requires compensation.
public_law_2.exp: Usually required for proportionality, but can be taken without in exceptional circumstances (Jahn v Germany).

public_law_2.q: The HRA 1998 has 'horizontal effect' in private litigation via s.6.
public_law_2.exp: Courts as public authorities must act compatibly (Campbell v MGN).

public_law_2.q: A constable can stop and search without suspicion under s.60 CJPO 1994.
public_law_2.exp: If authorised by a senior officer in anticipation of violence.

public_law_2.q: Code A of PACE governs the detention of suspects.
public_law_2.exp: Code A governs Stop and Search; Code C governs Detention.

public_law_2.q: Reasonable suspicion for stop and search can be based on a person's previous convictions.
public_law_2.exp: Code A 2.2B; cannot be based on personal factors alone.

public_law_2.q: A constable must provide their name and station before a stop and search.
public_law_2.exp: s.2(3) PACE; GOWISELY protocol.

public_law_2.q: An arrest is lawful if the officer has reasonable grounds to believe it is necessary.
public_law_2.exp: s.24(5) PACE necessity criteria (e.g., prompt investigation).

public_law_2.q: A suspect can be detained for 36 hours on the authority of a superintendent.
public_law_2.exp: s.42 PACE; requires serious arrestable offence.

public_law_2.q: The maximum detention without charge (with warrant) is 72 hours.
public_law_2.exp: 96 hours (s.44 PACE).

public_law_2.q: Intimate searches can be authorized by an inspector.
public_law_2.exp: s.55 PACE; for Class A drugs or harmful articles.

public_law_2.q: A suspect has an absolute right to legal advice upon arrest.
public_law_2.exp: Can be delayed for up to 36 hours in serious cases (s.58 PACE).

public_law_2.q: Confessions obtained by oppression are automatically excluded.
public_law_2.exp: s.76(2)(a) PACE; court 'shall not allow' it.

public_law_2.q: Section 14 of the Public Order Act 1986 applies to processions.
public_law_2.exp: s.14 applies to public assemblies; s.12 applies to processions.

public_law_2.q: The police can ban a public assembly under s.14A POA 1986.
public_law_2.exp: s.14A allows banning trespassory assemblies; static assemblies can only have conditions.

public_law_2.q: Breach of the peace is a statutory offence.
public_law_2.exp: It is a common law concept (R v Howell).

public_law_2.q: Aggravated trespass (s.68 CJPO 1994) requires intent to intimidate or disrupt.
public_law_2.exp: Must be on land in the open air.

public_law_2.q: Section 5 POA 1986 covers conduct that causes 'harassment, alarm or distress'.
public_law_2.exp: Lowest level public order offence.

public_law_2.q: Violent Disorder (s.2 POA 1986) requires 12 or more persons.
public_law_2.exp: Requires 3 or more persons (s.1 requires 12 for Riot).

public_law_2.q: Affray (s.3 POA 1986) can be committed in private.
public_law_2.exp: Can occur in public or private places.

public_law_2.q: A s.60AA order allows police to require removal of face coverings.
public_law_2.exp: To prevent identity concealment during disorder.

public_law_2.q: Kettling (containment) is always a deprivation of liberty under Article 5.
public_law_2.exp: Austin v UK; not a deprivation if proportionate and for a limited time to prevent breach of peace.

public_law_2.q: Organisers of a public procession must give 6 clear days' notice.
The Home Secretary can ban processions in London without the Commissioner's request.
public_law_2.exp: Commissioner must request the ban; Home Secretary consents (s.13 POA).

public_law_2.q: Reasonable force can be used to prevent a breach of the peace.
public_law_2.exp: Common law power available to citizens and police.

public_law_2.q: Evidence obtained unfairly can be excluded under s.78 PACE.
public_law_2.exp: Discretionary exclusion if admission would adversely affect fairness.

public_law_2.q: A 'Caution' must be given upon arrest.
public_law_2.exp: Code C, Para 10; 'You do not have to say anything...'

public_law_2.q: Failure to record an interview is a breach of Code E.
public_law_2.exp: Interviews must be audio recorded.
